results.name: Sci-fi miniatures
results.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

key_work.title: Blade Runner 2049
key_work.brief_description:
Blade Runner 2049 captures the cyberpunk idea of “low life and high tech”. The technology in this world isn’t used to help people but to control them. Despite the LAPD tower looming over the city, there is no government. A rich industrialist controls the city, gaining enormous power from synthetic farming. In the rain-soaked, neon-lit streets below, replicant cop K (Ryan Gosling) searches for his purpose and identity while ‘retiring’ his own kind. The film raises important questions about the ethics of creating sentient beings only to oppress them. It reflects real-world issues like artificial intelligence, exploitation, inequality and the power held by a wealthy elite.

World-building strengthens these themes, showing a decaying, industrial future.
The city is dark, with light only coming from huge holographic ads for real brands. This stands in stark contrast to the shiny, golden corporate spaces. Despite the grim portrayal, K’s journey of self-discovery provides a small hope that individual choices and kindness can lead to a better future. If an android can break free from its programming, perhaps we can overcome the grip of technology and big corporations.

Building Blade Runner 2049
Wētā Workshop built these detailed ‘bigature’ sets to create the futuristic Los Angeles. Cinematographer Alex Funke filmed these scaled sets, capturing the look of real surfaces and lighting. Each of the 38 models took about a week to construct, paint and weather. Art director Steven Saunders described these miniatures as “a composition of tiny vignettes” that form a rich visual world. According to Funke, this world shows that “technology and commerce have moved on, but everybody else has been left behind.”

Inside Blade Runner 2049’s bigatures
A major challenge for the film was to evolve the iconic world created in the original Blade Runner (1982). Its famous cyberpunk landscapes were built using miniatures, and BR2049 continued this painstaking process. Director Denis Villeneuve wanted to “film the world in a practical way,” using real effects to ground the futuristic visuals.

This time, digital cameras and motion rigs replaced some of the older methods, but the technique was still precise. The 38 miniature buildings in the cityscape were scaled and hand-painted, featuring great attention to detail – right down to tiny graffiti and worn window frames. Layers of paint, hairspray and other aging techniques gave the buildings a lived-in look. Blending these practical models with digital effects created an illusion of depth and history in every shot, enhancing the cyberpunk atmosphere.

links.description: Ridley Scott’s science-fiction classic Blade Runner was considered groundbreaking for its use of miniatures to create the film’s futuristic urban landscapes. Weta Workshop in New Zealand used the same techniques for the sequel under the supervision of miniature artist Alex Funke - but this time they were bigatures!

constellations_other.name: Hard sci-fi to cyberpunk
constellations_other.description: Ayoung Kim's practice has been inspired by 'hard' science fiction writers like Greg Egan. Recent sci-fi media using hard sci-fi can be connected back to the beginnings of cyberpunk, a sub-genre of sci-fi.

constellations_other.name: Directions of storytelling
constellations_other.description: Panoramic slides gave magic lanternists the ability to progress narratives by adjusting slides left or right. This movement is emblematic of a panning shot where the camera follows the action the natural way your head moves.

end.title: Memoir of a Snail – Pinky's puppets
end.creator_credit: Adam Elliot
end.brief_description:
Assorted Pinky Puppets:
Pinky pineapple puppet
Pinky floating in the dead sea puppet
Hippy Pinky puppet
Pinky perm puppet
Adult Pinky puppet
Testicle Pinky puppet

Pinky is an eccentric older woman who Grace meets at the local library when she’s sent to Canberra. From floating in the dead sea and bathing with snow monkeys to dancing in a schnitzel bar and outliving two husbands, Pinky has stories to tell and becomes a colourful beacon of support and hope to Grace. Pinky’s character is expressed through her wrinkled and puckered mouth. A team of artists made over a thousand plasticine mouths to make the characters talk, along with hundreds of eyeballs with magnetic pupils, which express the characters’ emotions. A team of stop-motion animators spent thousands of hours moving each character one frame at a time to bring them to life.

links.description: Like Kim Kong, renown filmmaker Adam Elliot and his team built multiple versions of the characters in Memoir of a Snail. To bring them to life over 1000 mouths were made to let the characters speak.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

start.title: Selena
start.creator_credit: Moctesuma Esparza and Robert Katz
start.brief_description: In this biographical drama, Selena Quintanilla is born into a musical Mexican-American family in Texas. Her father, Abraham, realizes that his young daughter is talented and begins performing with her at small venues. She finds success and falls for her guitarist, Chris Perez, who draws the ire of her father. Seeking mainstream stardom, Selena begins recording an English-language album which, tragically, she would never complete.

end.brief_description: In this biographical drama, Selena Quintanilla is born into a musical Mexican-American family in Texas. Her father, Abraham, realizes that his young daughter is talented and begins performing with her at small venues. links.description: One of the most unusual and trippy television shows in recent years, Legion took a hard-left turn from conventional storytelling in the X-Men universe. Carlos López Estrada directed an episode from the final season, a year after the release of his film Blindspotting.

links.description: The Good Lord Bird follows freedom fighters crossing America to end slavery in the 1850s. The first female filmmaker in Saudi Arabia, Haifaa Al-Mansour, directs a pivotal episode and made her debut with the documentary Women Without Shadows about the female role in Saudi society.
